Meta.ShortDescription: Water entering the lungs causes a muscle spasm that constricts the trachea and blocks the passage of both water and air, resulting in hypoxyia and eventual irreversible cerebral damage due to anoxia.

Symptoms.Symptom: Head low in the water, mouth at water level
Head tilted back with mouth open
Eyes glassy and empty, unable to focus
Eyes open, with fear evident on the face
Trying to swim in a particular direction but not making headway
Trying to roll over on the back to float
Uncontrollable movement of arms and legs, rarely out of the water.

Causes.Cause: Breath-hold under voluntary control until the urge to breathe due to hypercapnia becomes overwhelming.
Fluid is aspirated into the airways and/or swallowed
Cerebral anoxia stops breathing and aspiration
Cerebral injury due to anoxia becomes irreversible

RiskFactors.RiskFactor: Behavioral factors, such as alcohol use, or free access to water.

Diagnostics.Diagnostic: Through observation of signs and symptoms

Treatments.Treatment: Rewarming, usually through warmed IV fluids, or introducing heated O2 into the lungs
Elevation of the head, if there is no suspiction of neck injury
Muscle relaxants if needed to treat respiratory failure
Maintenance of blood sugar levels and normal body temperature.

Prognoses.Prognosis: Drowning victims who arrive at a hospital with spontaneous circulation and breathing usually recover with good outcomes.
If treated within 0-5 minutes, 10% chance of death, which increases to nearly 100% at 25 minutes.
